text: COSTELLO's profile passes in a dark room.
Years ago, we had the Church. That was only a way of saying we had each other. The Knights of Columbus were head-breakers. They took over their piece of the city.

The neighborhood. 1980's. We won't be here long. This isn where Costello ends up. It's where he began. Liquor store with shamrocked signs. MEN FISHING near Castle Island. Catholic SCHOOLKIDS playing in an asphalted schoolyard.

Twenty years after an Irishman couldn't get a job, we had the presidency. That's what the niggers don't realize. If I got one thing against the black chaps it's this. No one gives it to you. You have to take it.
COSTELLO comes in. The shop is one that sells papers, sundries, fountain drinks...and fronts a bookie operation
(leaning over cluttered counter) Don't make me have to come down here again.
Won't happen again, Mr. C.

The frightened proprietor hands over money. Fifty bucks, hundred, doesn't matter. COSTELLO is never the threatener His demeanor is gentle, philosophical. Almost a shrink's probing bedside manner. He has great interest in the worl as he moves through it. As if he originally came from a different world and his survival in this one depends on c continual observation and analysis. YOUNG COLIN looks up. CLOSE ON his eyes. He is fourteen o fifteen, but small for his age. Bookish. COSTELLO eyes the proprietor's TEENAGE DAUGHTER, working behind the counter. He takes a propane lighter, and, strangely, pays for it (the proprietor startled) and wait for change. He lights a MORE cigarette with the lighter.
Carmen's developing into a fine young lady. You should be proud. You get your period yet, Carmen?
The PROPRIETOR is uneasy. COSTELLO turns to YOUNG COLIN (about 14) staring at the local hero. Costello reaches up above and behind the counter and takes down some cigarett
You Johnny Sullivan's kid?
COLIN nods.
You live with your grandmother?
COLIN nods.
Yeah.
COSTELLO tells the Proprietor to takes three loaves of br and some soup off the shelves and puts them in Colin's ba
Get him three loaves of bread. And a couple of half gallons of milk. And some soup.
He goes over to the fridge and puts two half gallons of m in the bag. Some soup. Costello turns to Colin.
Do you like comic books?
Colin nods.   He adds a couple of comic books. When the PROPRIETOR looks at him, he takes out the money put in his pocket and gives back half.
You do good in school?
YOUNG COLIN nods, holding the big bag of loot.
Yes.
That's good. I did good in school. They call that a paradox.
He gives some money to Carmen.
Buy yourself some makeup. Keep the change.
Looks intently at COLIN to see if he gets it.    Colin do
You ever want to earn a little extra money, you come by L street. You know where I am on L street.
COLIN nods: everybody does.
Thank you.
He pushes out with the bags of groceries. The PROPRIETOR can do shit about it. YOUNG COSTELLO watches YOUNG COLIN go off down a slummy street.
YOUNG COLIN, the good boy, the very good boy, is serving funeral Mass. Various views of the church. Stained-glass light. The altar is still wreathed in the smoke of incens

To you, O Lord we commend the soul of Alphonsus, your Servant; in the sight of this world he is now dead; in your sight may he live forever. Forgive whatever sins he committed through human weakness and in your goodness grant him everlasting peace.
Amen.
CLOSE on COLIN'S face.
May the angels lead you into paradise; May the martyrs come to welcome you and take you to the holy city, The new and eternal Jerusalem.
A liturgical bell tings.
COSTELLO is talking informally (we realize that this is a continuation of the philosophical talk, the shadowy pacin YOUNG KIDS. Useful young men. YOUNG COLIN, three years ol is among them.
Church wants you in your place. What sort of man wants to be kept in his place? Do this don't do that, kneel, stand, kneel, stand...I mean if you go for that sort of thing...
YOUNG COLIN, the recent altar boy, visibly doesn't go for that sort of thing.
I don't know what to do for you. A man makes his own way. No one gives it to you. You have to take it. (a beat) Non serviam.
James Joyce.
Him and Lucifer. And me. (to the room) Guineas from the North End and down Providence, tried to tell me what to do...And something maybe happened to them.
Rose-colored dawn. YOUNG COSTELLO, with a pistol, execute MAN kneeling in the surf. She falls on the body of a man has just been executed.
Jeez, she fell funny.
FRENCH moves forward with an axe in his hand.
Frank, you gotta see somebody.
They go about their business.
YOUNG COSTELLO walking, talking...Not continuous with the above. We see that only YOUNG COLIN is present.
You decide to be something, you can be it. That's what they don't tell you, the Church.
MISTER FRENCH is doing books off behind a window of dirty glass.
When I was your age, they would say, we become cops or criminals. Today, what I'm saying to you is this: When you are facing a loaded gun...
very close on COSTELLO, holding Colin's shoulder.
What's the difference?
ECU: COLIN'S EYES swerve up. We are now on (MATURE) COLIN EYES eyes. This is how the character transits the "age leap"...on the unchanging eyes.
Pull back to reveal: POLICE TRAINEES. (INCLUDING BARRIGAN, who is included in Colin's trainee scenes). COLIN is in the class, wearing a trainee's uniform. He has a notebook, a pen. Writing.

The slug enters the skull by forming a small entrance hole. Blood and brain matter is ejected backwards from this hole. The bullet, which may expand, fragment or tumble, then passes through the brain...
COLIN writes.
POLICE TRAINEES ON A FIRING RANGE. As we go along the lin see COLIN, firing dry and then speed-changing a clip in a BERETTA 92F. He is a perfect trainee.

STATE POLICE TRAINEES standing in a pissing rain, a DI yelling at them OS. COLIN is staring forward. RAIN stream down his face. His opinion on the experience is not decipherable. Ad libs: "Sir, yes, sir."

Guys we recognize from the previous shots at the State Po Academy (wearing Statie t-shirts), including COLIN and BARRIGAN, are playing rugby against some FIREFIGHTERS. Ve rough game. The game breaks up with each group giving eac other the finger. FIREFIGHTERS are moving away triumphant
Fucking firemen are getting pussy for the first time in the history of fire. Or pussy.
COLIN sits on a bench looking at THE GOLD DOME OF BEACON HILL. The terraces of fine townhouses. Aqueous golden lig behind. Misty golden beauty.
What are you looking at? Forget it. Your father was a janitor, and his son's only a cop.
(not vainglorious, but innocently stretching for the idea) You're in trouble if you're "only" anything.
Don't tell me I'm looking at the first dickhead-American president of the United States.
COLIN doesn't have a great sense of humor but he knows ho pretend that he does. He smiles.

head_text.subj: EXT. STATE POLICE GRADUATION CEREMONY. DAY

text: Bagpipes and bullshit. Flags cracking. Line after line of paramilitary-looking graduates, among them COLIN.

The Massachusetts State Police has a long tradition of excellence. Your graduation today solidifies your acceptance into one of the finest law enforcement agencies in our nation. As the Governor of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, I am confident each and every one of you will serve with distinction, honor and integrity.
CAMERA swirls around COLIN as he moves, a lone person, through the breaking up crowd. Other graduates are hugged family. COLIN, alone, comes to the gates of the yard.
Congratulations. You are dismissed.
The bagpipe band plays "Minstrel Boy."
AN OLDSMOBILE. COSTELLO and MISTER FRENCH standing by the car.

COLIN walks over to the car. COSTELLO gives COLIN a BOX. COLIN flips open the top and then quickly closes it. NOTE The box could contain an eyeball, money, drugs, a picture Colin fucking his school teacher...we will never know.
School's out. You earned it. Yeah, no more teachers, no more books.

A test is reversed on a desk lit with fluorescents. BILLY takes up a Number Two pencil. He is in a room full of trainees, far enough along in their traineeship that thei hair has grown in. A CLOCK TICKS, sweep hand coming around. BILLY'S EYES on it.
Begin.
BILLY takes the test, marking multiple choice answers swi while all around him trainees are sweating and still tryi to read the questions.
BILLY, wearing a State Police sweatshirt is running, alongside BROWN a black trainee with specs.
She tells me, you never finish anything. (puff puff) You finish the police course you get taken care of again baby. (puff puff) So after graduation (puff puff) I get a blowjob again.
That's great. Your mom must be a wonderful woman.
Fuck yourself.
Look at it this way, you're a black guy in Boston. You don't need any help from me to be completely fucked.
Ways to get ahead, though, man, ways to get ahead.
(exasperated by this) To where. (Yeah)
BROWN is left thinking about this.
BILLY with other trainees is being braced by a DI.
This is not the regular police. This is the state police. Your training will illustrate the difference. What's the difference?
(sotto voce to BROWN) Rage issues and lower median IQ.
You say something?
Sir, I was agreeing with you about our obvious superiority to other forms of police, sir.
We're not superior, we're the best.
Sir, yes sir.
BILLY, in glasses and ear-protectors, waiting for the tar Go from the GUN to

COLIN, four years a veteran of the gang unit, is on the j on a raid, clearing rooms, part of a team working with massive aggression. He moves through a door. A SAD SACK O SHIT is throwing drugs out a window.
(calling to other cops) Douchebag!
COPS enter past Colin and pigpile the man. COLIN is chewi gum, all testosterone and aggression, glad to be a cop. T smartest guy in the room.
BILLY fires, and changes clips.

head_text.subj: EXT. A STREET IN BOSTON. DAY

text: A BLACK-WINDOWED, MODERN, POLICE BUILDING, beetling over plaza. Older Boston reflected in the featureless glass. T Boston of this film is almost futuristic. COLIN looks up the building with great intensity. He puts on his sunglas and walks towards the door.
COLIN, in civvies (a very good suit), stands at suave attention before CAPTAIN QUEENAN, a mild and scholarly ma who might as well be a Jesuit history-teacher.
Congratulations on passing the detective exam, and welcome to the Special Investigation Unit.
(tonelessly) Whoop-di fuckin' do.
We won't be working directly together, you'll be working for Captain Ellerby, but I like to see everybody. (contemplating him) You're a worker, you rise fast.
Like a twelve year old's dick. (Alt: Like a turd in the pool.)
Thank you, Sergeant.
My pleasure.
(to Queenan) Thank you, sir.
He turns to go.

head_text.subj: INT. QUEENAN'S OFFICE WAITING ROOM. DAY

text: As COLIN leaves the office, looking very satisfied and no little saturnine (it's not as if he isn't pleased by recognition and it's not as if he won't get revenge on Dignam), he barely glances--and does not actually see--th TRAINEE sitting off to one side. He sees polished brogues and walks on.
(whispering, joyful, in love with COLIN) Congratulations.
Thanks, hon.
As COLIN leaves she moderates her expression and:
(coldly) You can go in there now.
BILLY looks up. He has not seen COLIN, and COLIN has not him. He has his interview on his mind.
BILLY stands at attention. The picture of a spit-and-poli trainee.
You can sit.
BILLY does.
So.
BILLY has no idea why he is in this room with the brass. Sgt. Dignam is staring at him aggressively, with contempt stirring his coffee. DIGNAM is more intelligent than he seems.
Do you know what we do here?   My section?
BILLY doesn't want to answer unless he can answer correct
Sir, yes, sir, I have an idea...
Whoa, let's say you have no idea and leave it there. No idea. Zip, none. If you had an idea about what we do we would not be good at what we do. We would be cunts. Are you calling us cunts?
BILLY wouldn't normally take crap from this guy; but he d He's openly intrigued by the situation. Dignam is staring him. BILLY looks evenly at QUEENAN.
(not looking up from papers) Staff Sergeant Dignam has a style of his own. I'm afraid we all have to deal with it.
(getting to business, hard) You have family connections down in Southie. Through your father. Tell us about your uncle Jackie.
Uncle Jackie was a carpet layer for Jordan Marsh.
Uncle Jackie was a small-time bookie who tended bar at the Vets in Somerville.
He got popped by Nicastro in '95. They found his body out by the airport.
BILLY says slowly:
That's right. (tightly) I remember his funeral.
(cruelly) Closed casket?
That's right.
You tell anybody at Deerfield - that is, before you got kicked out for whaling on a gym teacher with a folding chair - you had an uncle met his demise like that?
BILLY says nothing. Eyes luminous.
I got a question. How fucked up are you?

COLIN, in his good suit, moves along the hall. He owns th building. He looks into offices. He is looking at his fut From one room BARRIGAN (still working in uniform) gives h the thumbs up. COLIN gets a coffee. He looks at a secreta ass. Caught at it, he smiles beautifully. She smiles back
What you got? (with admiration and envy) "Staff Sergeant". In four years you're a sergeant.
SIU. What a country.
(after a beat) Perfect.
Meaning to some extent "Perfect for a dick like you". Thi how friends come apart. BARRIGAN is unable to continue hi pose of congratulation. COLIN (close on Colin) is on to h
I don't mind going it alone. If you could go it alone you might get somewhere yourself.
We're cops. This isn't "somewhere".
I know you're a worker. I might be able to do something for you. You got any suits at home or you like coming to work looking like you're gonna invade Poland.
BILLY is still at attention. DIGNAM going with wet thumb through papers.

Let's look at the rest of the family tree. Your maggot uncle Tommy Costigan--he's another goof-- got busted selling guns to federal officers. Among many, many, many other departures from, ah, "normative behavior".
QUEENAN is inspecting Billy, watching his reactions. Spec catching light.
What's this got to do with me?
Why are you pretending to be a cop?
COLIN is eyeing a woman COP across the table. She smiles him and lowers her eyes. At the end of the table:
This unit is new, and you are the newest members of it. You have been selected for it on the basis of intelligence and aptitude.

This is an elite unit. Our job is to smash--or at least marginally disrupt-- (he gets the laugh he expected) --organized crime in this city by our own efforts and by enhanced cooperation with the FBI, represented here by Agent Frank Lazio-- (show the deeply unreliable dandy LAZIO) and we will do it. And by organized crime in this city...you know who we mean.
SURVEILLANCE PHOTOS come up. COSTELLO in sunglasses stand in front of the Autobody shop. COSTELLO standing with UNC JACKIE COSTIGAN.
(clicking the button) That's Jackie Costigan...that's an old picture. Jackie met his demise.
Last known photograph.
MORE RECENT PHOTOS. FITZY, DELAHUNT, FRENCH, all photogra with COSTELLO. Coming out of buildings, talking on the street, getting into cars.

Costello uses three key guys. There's Fitzy...off the boat psycho...lives in Brockton with his mother who looks like she's straight out of "Going My Way"... There's Delahunt, muscle, and here's French...the number one. But of course the rock star is...[you know who]
A picture of COSTELLO comes up. COLIN looks at it. In the SHOT Costello is serene, untouchable legally, untouchable the heart. He's like a hilarious devil.
We've done a briefing book. Read up.
I want to have any and all ideas, so I can pass them off as my own. (laughter, a long beat) Do your jobs and you will rise fast. You're in the best position in the department. Let's go to work.
The recruits disperse into a glittering modern office. CO in his flash suit, gets a cup of coffee. He looks at the BRIEFING BOOK. He opens to a picture of COSTELLO.
DIGNAM still working Billy.
Your old man was a hump from Southie. Baggage-handler at the airport. Family's all criminals except your old man.
And one priest. Since you seem to know everything.

I ain't sure about him, either. (ALT: Last I heard he was happily married to a 12 year old boy and living on a beach in Thailand.) Family's dug into the Southie projects like ticks. Lifers down there. Three decker men at best. You grew up, however, up the North shore. La di (fuckin') da.
Dignam leans over Billy.

You were kind of a double kid, I bet, right? One kid with your old man. One kid with your mother. Upper middle class in the week, and then dropping your 'r's and hanging in the Southie projects with daddy the donkey on the weekends. I got that right?
BILLY, opened up expertly and crudely, stares with contai hatred.
You have different accents? You did, didn't you. (You little fuckin' snake.) You were different fuckin' people.
You a psychiatrist?

If I was I'd ask you why you're a Statie making thirty grand a year. And I think if I were Sigmund fucking Freud himself I wouldn't get an answer. So tell me, what's a lace curtain motherfucker like you doing in the Staties?
Well. Families are always rising or falling in America. Am I right?
(appreciative, kindly, looking up from his papers) Who said that?
Hawthorne.

SGT. DIGNAM (although he knows perfectly well who Hawthor is) makes a fart-noise with his mouth. BILLY looks at him with an "I'm going to kill you" expression which is not without wit and which Dignam seems to admire.
What's the matter, smartass? You don't know any fuckin' Shakespeare?
We have a question. You want to be a cop, or do you want to appear to be a cop. It's an honest question. Lot of guys want to appear to be cops. Gun. Badge. Pretend they're on TV...
A lot of em just want to slam a nigger's head through a plate glass window.
I'm all set without your personal job application, Sergeant.
(after a "we got a live one" glance at Queenan) What the fuck did you say to me, trainee?
BILLY looks at him, and then looks forward.
Sir, with all due respect, sir, what is it you want from me?
Hey asshole, he can't help you. I know what you are, and what you aren't. I'm the best friend you ever had on the face of the earth. I'm gonna help you understand something: You're no fuckin' cop.

He's right. (Billy looks at Queenan) We deal in deceptions here. But what we don't deal with is self- deception. In five years, you might be anything else in the world, but you won't be a Massachusetts State trooper.
You sure of that?
I'm sure of that.
Guaranteed.
(looking up from his papers) You don't have much family.
(deciding this on the spot) I don't have any family.

A TROLLEY goes past. HOSPITAL HILL, above the trolley lin is sinister, quiet. HOSPITAL at the top like a malign fortress, above rows of endlessly repeated condominiums. BILLY CROSSES from the Trolley stop, desperately, an angr young man at his life's turning point.

BILLY'S MOTHER lies as if floating in her bed. Tubes, lig A bald head on a barely-dented pillow. She is a cancer patient in a coma, weighing possibly 80 lbs. Gasping for Her airways are cleared with a suction tube. BILLY sits watching as the tube goes in. BILLY sits looking at her.

BILLY is leaning against a wall. A maternal WASP UNCLE, a bright guy (pretensions, rather than status), speaks brie to a DOCTOR further along the hall, then approaches BILLY hands in the pocket of a good suit.
What's this I hear from Stephanie about you becoming a policeman?
You mean Stephanie who was the only one who came to my father's funeral? That Stephanie?
That Stephanie.
Nothing much to it Uncle Edward.
Are you trying to prove something to the family?
When you say "family", what do you mean? You?
You always question everything, don't you?

Yeah, well, maybe it would have done you some good to have a question from time to time. "Am I an asshole?" "Are my kids a mess?" "Is my wife a money-grubbing whore?" Those are questions. (the UNCLE starts to leave) "Have I been good to my dying sister or am I just pretending to be?" (he's stung THE UNCLE) Too late now, right?
Do you need some money for the funeral?
THE UNCLE moves away, bends to get his overcoat.
When my mother dies we don't have any connection. You got it?
AERIAL. FLY FROM the HOSPITAL TO:

head_text.subj: THE GOLD DOME ON BEACON HILL

location: AN APARTMENT ON BEACON HILL. TWILIGHT

text: A REALTOR switches on lights. An empty, flash apartment a the Parisian rooftops of Beacon Hill. A view of the Dome. More than you'd think a cop could afford. We see, as COLI does, beyond his reflection in the glass, the STATE HOUSE DOME.
This is it. Nice. You've got high ceilings, parquet floors. There's a lock on the fridge in case you have eating issues.... Joke...not a very good one. (uneasy) So, you're a policeman?
(like something he is used to reciting) I'm a State Police detective.
(wondering where he gets his money from) State Police Detective. You a married State Police Detective?
(coming out of his reverie and coldly:) ...No.
Oh, cuz it's big and I wondered if a cop...
I have a cosigner.
You intend to have a housemate. That's cool.
Give me the fuckin' papers.
BILLY sits on a bench looking out over the whole city. (I the best view of Boston, never seen in a film). He's smok a cigarette, making his decision.
Continuation of the interview.
So what do I do?

During the war, Churchill used river mines. He'd float them down the rivers into Germany. They'd either hit something, or not. That's what we'll use you for. I'll float you down the river. The rest will happen. Or it won't... (a beat)
By the way, this isn't police work for peanuts. There's money behind this operation. You won't be paid as a cop, but there is a bonus involved. Tax free.
QUEENAN writes on a slip of paper and hands it to BILLY. BILLY looks up from the paper, impressed.
Luck of the Irish. All that and you're still young enough to fuck undergraduates.
We can't conceal that you've been a trainee. You'll be convicted of a crime. We're thinking that a guilty plea to assault and battery might make sense.
Given your nature.
You'll serve enough jail time to convince anyone that it's no set- up. You'll be on probation. The whole nine yards.
I need you, pal. You've already pretended to be a Costigan from South Boston.
BILLY looks up with a glazed insolence. In one beat he is a scared trainee but a smart criminal.
Every weekend...Sergeant.
Perfect.
Do it again. For me.
BILLY throws down his cigarette. He has decided.
Priest's cassock whipping in the wind. A few mourners (sh genteel ladies, contemporaries of his mother), but Billy seems to have no real connection with any of them.
BILLY is alone at the grave. He looks at the tags on wind blown wreaths. One gives him pause. Under a picture of Th Virgin it reads: "Heaven holds the Faithful Departed" and signed: "F. Costello".
A CELL DOOR CLOSES. On Billy. Looking like a real crimina Not a pretend one. Frightened and resolute at once. BILLY in a holding tank.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE BALCONY OF COLIN'S APARTMENT. MORNING

text: COLIN, in a bathrobe, leans on the rail and looks at Bost THE GOLD DOME visible. Colin drinks coffee. Not satisfied worried.
BILLY, naked, holds his clothes in a bundle. Being proces out of jail. Beside him another guy, furtive, gruff, not trying to be friendly.
You're Bill Costigan?
Who wants to know?
Nothin.' I know a Sean Costigan. L Street.
My cousin.
Connected but not too bright-- (BILLY looks at him with an only-I-can-insult-my- cousin look) No offense.
Billy gets his clothes.

On the wall is a rogues gallery of COSTELLO and all his primary guys...MISTER FRENCH, DELAHUNT, FITZY. COLIN and others sitting listening. COLIN, reading a paper (Boston Herald) which may or may not have the headline, CASE DROP AGAINST DRUGS CADET (featuring a picture of Billy), looks as SGT. DIGNAM comes in.
Sorry I'm late.
Staff Sergeant Dignam is our liaison with the undercover section. Their undercover work is extensive. He's here to give us his report. Sgt. Dignam.

OK. They're out there, my people. They're like the fuckin' Indians. You're not gonna see them. You're not gonna hear about them except through me or Captain Queenan. You will not, ever, know the identity of undercover people. This shit hole, unfortunately, has more fuckin' leaks than the Iraqi navy.
Fuck yourself.
I'm tired from fucking your wife.
How's your mother?
Good. She's tired from fucking my father. (opens a FILE) OK, today, girls, what I got for you is microprocessors.
LAZIO, the Fed, comes in and sits down. With folders, pen

Somebody, as you may already know, stole one hundred microprocessors from the Mass Processor Corp out Route 128. They're the kind of processors they put into computers that can put a cruise missile up the ass of a camel from the other side of the planet. That's what they do out there on "America's Technology Highway". Worth a hundred grand apiece. Guy worked for the company two months walked out the door with a box of processors on Tuesday, has a ticket booked for Florida on Wednesday, but on Thursday he gets found in a dumpster. You know where this dirt ball started his life? Southie projects.
What was his name? The, ah, departed.
Myles Kennefick. Got the job with a forged UMass transcript. UMass Boston, which incidentally happens to be in...
South Boston?
Who forged your transcript, dickhead?
I know that guy. His father runs the Hibernian Liquor Mart. Kennefick's.
We are not here to solve the "Case of the Dead Scumbag". We are here to nail Costello.
COLIN stands down, embarrassed.

We got a guy says that   he hears Costello is moving the   processors to China...that he set   up the whole fuckin' job and popped   Kennefick. (LAZIO is writing, lawyerish.) You don't want to miss   it if Costello takes a dump.
We'd miss less if your informants were available to us, and of course to the FBI (Bureau)...
Without asking for details, do you have anyone in with Costello presently?
Maybe. Maybe not. Maybe fuck yourself. My theory on Feds is they're like mushrooms. Feed 'em shit and keep in the dark. You girls have a nice day.

head_text.subj: EXT. A STREET OF TENEMENTS IN SOUTHIE. DAY

text: BILLY steps off a bus at a corner. He goes up to a house, knocks on the door. A Southie hag answers. On an oxygen cylinder, smoking.
Billy?
BILLY nods.
Aunt Cathy?
His aunt takes her cigarette out of her mouth and then embraces him fiercely. BILLY takes it like the imposter h is. But he might well love his aunt.
Good to see you. Good to see you.
BILLY is eating soup.
They said you were in the Staties, I couldn't believe it.
I got kicked out about four months ago.
It was in the papers.
Sean is a villain leaning in a doorway. Bad tie: he takes off. He has been at a funeral.
Well. So you know.
And why are we graced with your presence?
I brought your mother some pictures of my father.
It's true. They are on the table.
My mother had them. My mother's dead.
(reflexively) I'm sorry. I'm sorry for your troubles.
Sean opens the fridge, opens a beer, and hands it to BILL He opens one for himself.
I was at a funeral myself. Myles Kennefick, knew him in school. Beat the fuck out of him seven or eight times as a matter of fact. (affably to Billy) You workin'?
No.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE PORCH OF THE THREE-DECKER. LATER

text: Sean and BILLY are still drinking beer.
When did I see you after that?
Not for a long time. Down the cape after Rose's wedding. I think.
Fuck, oh shit. I remember that, dude. I had that fuckin' buck knife, right, and I cut all the brass numbas off the doors at the hotel. I was trippin'...All of them. That was a night.
Sean looks deflated.
Listen, I got twenty thousand dollars when my mother died. Insurance.
Yeah?
In your line of work, if I gave you ten thousand dollars what could you give me back?
My line of work... I'm not in that line of work just presently because I don't have ten thousand dollars. As a matter of fact I have never had ten thousand dollars.
That's what I'm saying.
Sean nods, and nods.
You know what we usually say at these moments.
You fuckin' moron. What are you talking about? I'm not a cop. I'm your cousin.
BILLY is waiting. Sean comes out of a squalid looking hou and gets into a car. Fast. Billy puts the car in gear.
Fuckin' Ricans think they know everything. If they knew shit they wouldn't be Puerto Ricans.
He has a paper bag full of money. He opens a beer.
(high as a kite) Double the money, double the fun. (confusing his TV jingles) Cinnamon toasty apple bun... R is for Ricans...P is for pigs...
They drive past a BPD cruiser. Sean hides his beer.
I can't stop drinkin.
BILLY laughs.
Why would you even think of stopping drinking?
He don't like it. He don't like drinkin...he don't like fightin... (Sean looks sad) ...he says stay out of the bars... You know, we're not even supposed to do this on this side of fuckin' Worcester.
Who says?
He says. Costello says. God says, as far as you're concerned.

head_text.subj: INT. A HORRIBLE BAR IN SOUTHIE. NIGHT

text: Sean, beyond wasted, is talking to some people, including MISTER FRENCH. A table wet with spilled beer.
Not a cop. He got out of the joint three weeks ago. Dead up. He talks like his shit don't stink but he's good people.
Cunt cop.
I knew his father. I liked his uncle Jackie better.
Uncle Jackie was excellent.
Fucking guineas.
They solemnly toast uncle Jackie and his fate among the fucking guineas. Across the crowded room, BILLY is orderi at the bar.
A cranberry juice.
It's a natural diuretic. My girlfriend drinks it when she got her period. (to BILLY) You got your period?

BILLY glances over at the table where MISTER FRENCH sits SEAN, and then smashes his glass into the face of the WEL DRESSED SCUMBAG. He stands waiting for the SCUMBAG to get he is grabbed and shoved against the wall by MISTER FRENC Popped into a pay phone hard. The pay phone comes off the hook.
Get your hands off me.
Do you know me?
No.
BILLY shakes his head no.

I'm the guy who tells you there are guys you hit and there are guys you don't. That's not quite a guy you can't hit, but it's almost a guy you can't hit, so I'm fucking ruling on it right now that you don't hit him, understand?
Yeah. Excellent. Fine.

I know you. I know your family. Also I know you do another drug deal with your idiot fucking cop- magnet cousin I'll forget your grandmother was very nice to me and cut your fucking nuts off. You understand that?
Yeah.
Now you know me.
Yeah.
A beat: they stare at each other.
What are you drinking?
Cranberry juice.
A beat.
What is it, your period?
BILLY laughs.
Get him a cranberry juice.
The WELL-DRESSED SCUMBAG is bleeding, incredulous. MISTER FRENCH takes him by the shoulder.
(sotto voce to WELL- DRESSED SCUMBAG) That's Jackie's nephew.
Oh...
Oh, what?
FRENCH demolishes him with body blows.
Get the fuck out of here.

head_text.subj: EXT. A HOUSING PROJECT IN SOUTHIE. DAY

text: COLIN and BARRIGAN (who Colin has moved to plain clothes) stand at the door, talking, or trying to talk, with a fea MRS KENNEFICK. MRS KENNEFICK looks like she starts drinki whiskey at 9 in the morning.

Mrs. Kennefick, Myles and I were in school together. Myles was behind me in school but I knew him. I will get those responsible. Don't you want to see us catch whoever used him to do a robbery and then killed him?
Allegedly.
(grimaces) "Allegedly".
If he was killed he probably did something wrong.
You don't mean robbery do you, Mrs Kennefick? That's not what you think he did wrong.
MRS. KENNEFICK notices COSTELLO driving by.
Costello and Gwen are in the car.    Gwen is dressed like Jackie O.
Wave to your girlfriend.

location: A HOUSING PROJECT IN SOUTHIE. DAY.

text: I mean fuck yourself.
She slams the door. As COLIN walks away from the door he notices the TAIL: a maroon sedan and a damaged white deli van.
You get that?
"Allegedly" or "fuck yourself?"
Welcome to the neighborhood.
FRENCH pulls up to a light. [COSTELLO blows a red light and leaves the tail (includin the Surveillance Van which we will see again) behind him snarl of traffic.]
Cut 'em here.
French steps on it and blows through the light, leaving t follow cars behind.
Bye, bye.

head_text.subj: INT. THE ELEVATOR AT POLICE HEADQUARTERS. DAY

text: COLIN boards with a bunch of other cops and workers. On board, directly beside him, is MADOLYN. COLIN's age, beautiful, wearing a business suit. She has a thick stack medical-looking files. She's a psychiatrist on contract t the Commonwealth of Massachusetts. She does probation counselling work with "violent offenders" and also sees policemen.
Making a house call?
Have I seen you professionally?
No, no. I know what you do. I know who you are.
MADOLYN nods, and then because this is a (relatively) sensitive subject ignores COLIN, but she is visibly attra by him.
When guys have to "use their "service revolvers" in the "course of duty" they get to talk to you about their "feelings" and whatnot.
MADOLYN laughs.
No. Oh, I know how it goes. You're a mental health professional.
(laughing) I have an appointment on this floor.
The door opens.
That's good. They're all fuckin' crazy on that floor. (points up) I'm one floor up.
Oh, fancy policeman.
That's right. Fancy.
Are you a Statie?
After she steps out he prevents the door from closing.
Yeah, I'm also getting my law degree.
Suffolk, nights?
They don't run Harvard Law at night, last time I checked.
When was the last time you checked?
Before I went to fucking Suffolk.
I went to U Mass. I wasn't insulting you.
Well I thought you were, and for that you have to take me to dinner.
Maybe you could shoot someone and I'd have to see you professionally.
Whatever it takes. I'll stab someone in the heart with an icepick right now if it gets me dinner with you.
MADOLYN hands him a card.
I don't need a card, I'm a detective.
She hesitates. He takes the card.
I'm only joking. Nice to meet you... "Madolyn".
The doors close. The elevator takes him up. He takes out cellphone as if he's forgotten something. As the doors op the signal bars light up, and the phone rings.

(walking, voice low) I didn't know about your tail until I saw it myself. I couldn't call, I had the other guy with me. Blue sedan and a white delivery van, fucked up with graffiti on the side. The van is audio surveillance. OK, have a nice day.

head_text.subj: INT. A COFFEE SHOP IN SOUTHIE. MORNING

text: The same shop in which YOUNG COSTELLO talked to YOUNG COL all those years ago. Two ITALIANS are in the shop, talkin hard to the Pakistani PROPRIETOR (SINGH). These are hard but they're not being threatening, just persistent: the g DOES owe them money. BILLY is finishing his breakfast. Watching. He goes over. The two GUINEAS are amazed. [Dial on separate document]. Billy is finishing his breakfast. Watching. He goes over.
You guys from Providence?

The GUINEAS look at him. The younger one moves to interve BILLY smiles and destroys them both. Maniacal violence. T biggest beatdown in gangster movie history--and obviously that's saying something. In the course of the beat-down B breaks his left hand--a "boxer's fracture". BILLY stands his victims, breathing hard, holding his broken hand.
What have you done to my place! Get out of here.
BILLY goes.
BILLY, unlit cigarette in his mouth, is having his hand wrapped in plaster by a lady doctor. In another life he m have dated her. Not in this one.

A romantic restaurant. The best Boston has (which isn't saying much, but whatever). COLIN, looking great, a man o the rise. MADOLYN in pearls, also looking great. But mayb the conversation has lapsed and the date gone south.
You also do probation work, right?
That's right. I see "violent offenders".
Bad guys.
That's one way to look at it.   Not necessarily.

COLIN wonders if she's breaking his balls. A DESSERT arri some towering Japanesey concoction with a fan of sugar ca spines, sitting in a pool of sauce. COLIN looks at it, fo poised. MADOLYN looks at it. He looks up at her.
That have this and they don't have duck l'orange.
MADOLYN smiles: she likes him. Even with the dinner-long bitterness over the duck l'orange.
Was your dinner OK?
(holding balloon of inappropriate wine) Oh, the lobster was excellent. I just thought, French restaurant...
The look at the dessert.
I'm waiting for you to make your move.
I don't know what you're gonna do, but if it moves I'm going to arrest it (shoot it).
MADOLYN laughs.    COLIN sees his shot: he's got her laug
What's it like having people "find themselves?" All day long people "finding themselves." Does it get messy with all those feelings flying around the room?
Why, does that make you uncomfortable?
Colin stares at her.    Water glass nearly goes over.
You know what Freud said about the Irish?
Yes I do.
If you actually do I'll see you again.
Who says I want to see you again?
(concerned, perhaps unexpectedly) Don't you?
Yes, course I do. (a beat) What Freud said about the Irish is We're the only people impervious to psychoanalysis.
MADOLYN is impressed.
Tough luck for you with a client list of Mick cops, isn't it. "Opening up"? Good luck to you.
COLIN laughs but looks nervous about the concept of "open up".
Why do you do it?
Some people do get better.
COLIN takes it seriously; admires it.
Fair enough.
Sometimes, though, I want people to forget about their personal bullshit and do their jobs.
Unsaid: Like I do.
Including the criminals?
If they don't do their jobs you don't have one.
Me? I'd just arrest innocent people. I'll arrest you right now.
You're trouble.
You don't know the half of it.

head_text.subj: INT. A HORRIBLE BAR IN SOUTHIE. NIGHT

text: A slow night. BILLY IS AT THE BAR bent over a glass of cranberry juice. The women available are two CRONES. [Dia on separate document]. Stark contrast to COLIN'S EVENING. BOOKMAKER on the phone. BILLY, by the glances of people looking at him, has made his bones. He's treated with respect. His hand and wrist in a cast. Out of nowhere (th Billy is aware conversation has stopped he does not look around)... COSTELLO sits down beside him AT THE BAR. BILLY observes: MISTER FRENCH sitting down at a far table. Watching. Cove the room. COSTELLO is brought a glass of water by the silent barten No sound whatsoever in the bar.
They say nothing, look at each other. BILLY notices DELAH and FITZY, entering. They stand by MISTER FRENCH. BILLY sits motionless.
Do you know who I am?
BILLY does: but shakes his head.
No.
You met my friend, Mister French the other night.
Is his real name Mister French?
No. (a beat) Come with me. (As BILLY hesitates) I'm not the cops. I'm not askin' you.
BILLY stands up. MISTER FRENCH stands up. BILLY, COSTELLO and MISTER FRENCH move towards the back room. As they wal the back room of the bar, we hear COSTELLO:
You know something, they just do not stop having the Mafia in Providence, and this can cause problems for me.

location: BACK ROOM OF THE BAR. CONTINUOUS.

text: Those guys you tuned up are connected down Providence. What they're going to do is come back up with some guys and kill you. Which, sure as you're born, they will do unless I stop them. Do you want me to stop them?
Is it something I can't do personally?
COSTELLO appreciates the balls of this. He looks at Miste French. Then back at Billy, smiling.
I'm going to have my associate search you.
BILLY tenses. Exactly as he might if he were wearing a wi
Search me? Search me for what?
MISTER FRENCH and COSTELLO look at each other.
C'm here.
Contra-fucking-band.    Take your fuckin' shoes off.
Shoes off.
BILLY slips out of them. MISTER FRENCH inspects the shoes COSTELLO'S cold eyes are on BILLY. MISTER FRENCH searches BILLY. Looks into his wallet. The wallet is emptied onto table.
I knew your father.
Yeah. He's dead.
I'm sorry.     How did he go?
He didn't complain.
That was his problem.
Who said he had a fuckin' problem.
I just said he had a fuckin' problem. There's a man could have been anything.
Are you saying he was nothing?
I'm saying he worked at the airport.
COSTELLO turns to MISTER FRENCH.
He's clean.
The arm.
With amazing violence MISTER FRENCH smashes the cast on t corner of a table. Billy drops to his knees in tears of p MISTER FRENCH sorts through the pieces of the cast. Ad li "such a fuckin' pussy."

(holding Billy by the collar) It makes me curious to see you in this neighborhood. Regressing. And, if I can slander my own formative environment, it makes me sad, this regressing. Plus, I don't know if it's beyond some cop prick like fucking Queenan to pull you out of the Staties, and send you after me. I just can't know. I don't know what they do in...that department, anyway.
He grabs Billy's broken right hand.
Are you still a cop?
No.
COSTELLO twists Billy's broken hand.
You swear on your mother's grave that you're not a cop.
I am not a cop.
You stop doing coke deals with your jerk-off cousin?
Yes!
COSTELLO lets go of Billy's hand. Billy is weeping on the floor. COSTELLO straightens his suit.
Take it easy. Get your hand taken care of. I'm sorry. It was necessary. As for our problem with Providence...let's not cry over spilled guineas.

head_text.subj: INT. THE MAIN PART OF THE BAR. MOMENTS LATER

text: COSTELLO, the visiting king, points at a group of drinker including a BLOND WOMAN (1st), GWEN.
What's this IRA motherfucker doing in my bar?
The IRA MOTHERFUCKER is terrified.
(slapping him on the back) Only kidding. How's your mother?
Ah, she's on her way out.
We all are. (straightens suit and tie) Act accordingly.
Costello exits.
MISTER FRENCH is methodically shelling and eating peanuts
Do you trust him?
These days, who's reliable?
His Uncle Jackie was.
The Costigans are talented in general.
You don't trust a guy behaves like he's got nothin' to lose.
I'm reliable.
And he is.
Well, you're one in a million.
Ten million.
What about your wife?
I thought she was.
She wasn't.
SILENT FLASH of MISTER FRENCH strangling his wife with a in a 70's bathroom.
She got reliable.
GWEN looks up:
Don't you people ever shut the fuck up?
"Another county heard from."
One too many.

SEAGULLS squabble over unusual food. POWER PLANT IN THE DISTANCE, the MTA-train going by. TWO BODIES lie in a tid ditch in the salt-marsh. They are the Italians who Billy fought in the restaurant. Hands taped together behind the backs. Two in the head each. COLIN is with the LYNN POLIC and the State Police forensics people. COLIN gets down an lifts a soaking lapel. Revealed is the tag of a men's sho Providence.
The principles of detection tell me that these men came from Providence.
I'd appreciate it if you got out of my crime scene.
This is my crime scene, but knock yourself out.
COLIN gets up. He walks back across the marsh. Opens his phone.
(walking) I saw a dead guy. I think I have post traumatic stress. You available for lunch? See you then.
At a PAY PHONE he dials another number.

head_text.subj: INT. COSTELLO'S CONDOMINIUM ON THE HARBOR. MORNING

text: One of Costello's homes.
Who's the lead detective?...Good, he's a moron.
BILLY cannot hear what COSTELLO is saying. He has an alum brace taped on his wrist and hand.
I want you to get the cops to look at Jimmy Pappas for the hit. Of course he had nothing to do with it and will say so. You look in
his car...and find...the gun that did it.
In the trunk or the glove box?... All right.
COLIN deadpan, appreciative, hangs up the phone. BARRIGAN walks in the middle distance, giving the man his privacy.
Wanna see some dead guys?

head_text.subj: INT. COSTELLO'S CONDOMINIUM ON THE HARBOR. MORNING

text: COSTELLO sits down in the breakfast area in his bathrobe. has a bowl of cornflakes.
Have a seat, Billy.
Thank you.
(he looks up) You know John Lennon?
BILLY sits. MISTER FRENCH are nearby.
Yeah, he was president before Lincoln.
(smiles) Lennon said `I'm an artist. You give me a fuckin' tuba and I'll get you something out of it'.
I'd like to squeeze some fuckin' money out of it.
COSTELLO and MISTER FRENCH look at each other.
Smart mouth. Too bad.
COSTELLO lifts a piece of plastic on the table revealing severed human hand. BILLY tries to conceal his shock.

QUEENAN and STAFF SGT. DIGNAM are listening to the live broadcast. QUEENAN is benign. Lights of equipment in his specs. INT. A CONDOMINIUM ON THE HARBOR. CONTINUOUS. COSTELLO takes the ring off the finger of the severed han Partial exchange with MISTER FRENCH. BILLY watches.
The point with John Lennon is a man can look at anything and make something out of it. For instance, I look at you and I think what can I use you for?
(giving the hand to Mister French) Get rid of this. (back to Billy) Maybe we can work something out. Let me get dressed.
He gets up.
BILLY runs the water in the sink. He starts to leave the bathroom and then impulsively takes off his wire and chuc it out the window as far as he can.
The wire falls into the water. INT. SURVEILLANCE OFFICE. CONTINUOUS. Queenan reacts mildly to the loss of the signal. He remov his headphones.
That was quick. He dead already?
A GREEK GUY (JIMMY PAPPAS) in chef's whites is cuffed and stuffed by TACTICAL OFFICERS. He has no idea what is goin on. COLIN and BARRIGAN follow.
This will get Captain Ellerby on the six o'clock news.
No wonder you get ahead.

head_text.subj: EXT. A STREET BY THE HARBOR. DAY

text: BILLY walking and talking on the phone.
I won't do it if I have to wear a wire. No wires. Ever, ever, you understand me? You don't know what this is like. (listens) Micro what?
Queenan on the phone.

Microprocessors. We'll probably be at war with the Chinese in twenty- odd years and Costello is selling them military technology. Microprocessors, chips, computer parts. Anybody says anything about anything like that, you let us know.
ELLERBY is before a thicket of microphones.
Did you have a tip from an informant?
No, it was tireless police activity that ah effected ah the arrest of the ah alleged perpetrator.
COLIN is rolling a quarter across the backs of his finger BROWN (last seen as Billy's friend) and BARRIGAN, new plainclothes recruits to Colin's special squad, sit acros from him.

I've been put in charge of this unit. It is a small surveillance sub-unit but it is mine. And I didn't take this job in order to fuck it up, or to let anyone else fuck it up, whosoever they may be. I hand picked this group. You are my A-team so I want you to conduct yourselves accordingly.
Through glass we see ELLERBY, preening. ELLERBY gives the thumbs up.

Hi, Captain. And our primary target is obviously Frank Costello. But we don't communicate with anyone else in this shop. Queenan is compartmentalizing everything in SIU. It's the right thing to do, personally I don't trust these fucking troopers either. We think we might have a problem. We think Costello's got a rat in the State Police.
Really?
Yeah.   Really.
Do we have direct access to Queenan's undercovers?
(not happy about this) No. Ah...not presently. Not presently. But I'm hoping to get things...reorganized. That's it. Congratulations. Don't disappoint me.
BROWN and BARRIGAN leave.       Colin leaves as well.
(to Brown) I know why I'm here. I made him feel guilty. Why are you here?
Intelligence and aptitude.
That's new.
COLIN opens his cell phone.
Hello Dad. I have a new job. (ALT: I got a promotion.)
MISTER FRENCH backhands a guy into a table of betting sli
Where's your fucking license? I don't see no fucking license.
What license.
BILLY, who is not wearing a cast anymore, watches.

There's no such thing as a license, of course, but you definitely have to have one. (grabs the bookie by the ear) If you are not being run by us you will be run by someone else, which means you will have let undesirable elements into Mr. Costello's area.
A HARD GUY sitting reaches inside his coat. BILLY in a fl breaks his jaw with a pistol barrel and then covers the sprawled HARD GUY with the gun.
(spitting teeth) I was going for my fucking cigarettes...
He was. They fall from his fingers.
Hey, that's Jimmy Bags. What the fuck you doin'?
What the fuck. I didn't know....
There's no profit if I pay him two grand a week. I'm in the hole if I pay him two grand a week.
Then make more money or go out of business. This is America. If you don't make money you're a fucking douchebag. What are you going to do?
Make more money.
That's the spirit.

head_text.subj: EXT. THE STREET OUTSIDE THE BOOKIE SHOP. LATER

text: BILLY and MISTER FRENCH emerge.
Very interesting.
Yeah, well. Fuck.
Don't worry about it. Guy didn't need need his teeth anyway. Maybe if he was an Eskimo. But in this country we eat a variety of items.
They get into COSTELLO'S CAR. Billy in the front seat. Mi French in the back.
He knocked Jimmy Bags teeth out.
COSTELLO does an Edgar Kennedy.
So?
He was...
Reaching for his cigarettes.
Okay! You gonna give me shit, it wasn't no reason----he put his hand in his coat! I don't know if he's a bookie or what the fuck he's doing...
(interrupting) Well, you know what the fuck a bookie does?
(to Costello) Pays you.
Bingo. Anyway, I like a guy who goes around knocking guys teeth out for no reason.
He takes out a cell phone and hands it to BILLY.
Here. From now on call the bar and ask for Mikey. Just Mikey. You ask for Mikey because there's no Mikey. Wait. We'll call.

Forty-eight hours from the time this phone first rings, you take the fucking chip out - like so - and you fucking destroy it. After three days a phone ain't clean. If you use a phone which is not clean, you will have a accident. You never call us. We call you. You got that?
I got it.
I can't fuckin' hear you.
I got it.

head_text.subj: INT. A HARBOR RESTAURANT. BOSTON. DAY

text: A lobster-bib kind of place. DAYTIME DRINKERS, MICKS in b boat shoes, hyper-aware of... COSTELLO and BILLY in a bac table. COSTELLO, having finished his lunch, is drawing. B is unused to being the subject of so many stares. He has of a coked-out nervousness, dirty hair.
Don't look. There's a white van across the parking lot?
WE see it through the smeared glass: the WHITE VAN we alw see. This time with a different magnetic business sign.
(lifting and looking at his sketch) They don't have directional microphones.
What, do you got x-ray vision?
(not taking his eyes off his sketch) They don't have directional microphones.
BILLY registers what seems to be inside information. COSTELLO looks over his half-glasses at Billy's untouched food. COSTELLO is sizing Billy up: has been thinking abou him.
People looking at you make you self- conscious?
BILLY shrugs. Indicating: Yeah, well, who the fuck wouldn be.
I don't know.
Why? They're minuses. They can't tell the difference between a rock star and a career criminal.
Anyone not a criminal is a minus?
What are you soft? That's not what I said. Eat something, Jesus Christ, we got a nice day by the water. Sun's shining, gulls are up...Nice smell of ozone...
TWO PRIESTS and a NUN are sitting two tables over. An old priest and a younger one. COSTELLO notices. THE NUN gets and leaves.

You know if your father were alive and saw you, sitting here with me, let's say he would have a word with me about this, in fact, he'd kill seven guys just to cut my throat. And he could do it, which is something you may not know about William Costigan, Sr.
He never, ah, I mean never?

He kept his own counsel. He never wanted money. You can't do a thing with a man like that. Your uncle Jackie needed a lot of money. But even though he got his money from me, he also would kill my entire fucking family if he saw me here with you. And I think about this.
So what are talking about here?
Fact is you're not a guy fresh from the zoo who wants to run a spring water distributor and I don't see you up the dog track as a general manager.
Look at it this way. It's like a tuba. I want to see if I can get something out of it.
COSTELLO smiles at this, then looks at his sketch.
You ever think of going back to school?
With all due respect, Mr. Costello, school's out.
Well that's your problem. Maybe someday you'll wake the fuck up.
He gets up and leaves the table, leaving BILLY sitting th COSTELLO stops to speak to the priests.
Good day, Fathers.
(terrified and simultaneously) Good morning [day], Francis, good morning.
The OLDER PRIEST is very nervous, looking around. The YOU PRIEST concerned for his elder but personally not implica COSTELLO leans over the OLDER PRIEST, a pathetic man.
You recall our chat? (the OLDER PRIEST nods, terrified) "I am as God made me", was that what you said? May I remind you, God don't run the bingo in this archdiocese.
May I remind you, Mr. Costello, that pride comes before the fall.
What comes before the Fall is the Summertime.
COSTELLO notices that THE NUN is heading back to the tabl
How is Sister Mary Theresa doing? We had a tasty relationship before she took her vows. Enjoy your clams, cocksuckers.
FITZY beats up a guy with a pipe.   Billy watches from th background.
FITZY and the Costello gang blow up a car as Billy watche Laughing, they hop in their vehicles and drive off.
OFFICE decorated with golf implements. ELLERBY has a hangover. Sunglasses. Eating baby aspirin by the small fistful.
I'm not making enough progress with Costello?

"Progress" is hard to define. I make progress every day. In fact, I'm making progress now. There are guys in this department make excellent progress for twenty years without ever getting anything you could definitively call a result. It's like any American industry. Nobody minds if you don't succeed as long as you don't fuck up.
He has a bowl of ice water on his desk.
Objectives get lost sight of: fair enough. Who did the two guys from Providence?
Jimmy Pappas.
And what happened to Jimmy Pappas?
He had a heart attack in jail and got knifed in his bed at Boston City Hospital. I believe it's been in the papers.
ELLERBY stares at COLIN.
Are you happy with this result?
It's a result.
Yeah, but cui bono? Who benefits.
Cui gives a shit. It's got a bow on it.
(with true appreciation) I think you are a cop, my son.
He drops his face into the bowl of ice water.

A stripped HOSPITAL BED stands in a fall of light. This i the apartment where his mother became ill. Billy has pack half of his mother's things into boxes--and then stopped. Billy doesn't use the bedroom. He sleeps on the couch amo boxes of pictures, papers, teacups wrapped in newspaper. BILLY is sitting on the couch. He reaches into a box and out photographs like cards. Scenes from his life. His for life. His family life, his life as a child, his romantic life. He sits and stares at the pictures. He rearranges t photographs in different ways.

FRENCH and BILLY break in, surprising the MAN (BRIAN), se at his dining room table. He throws a child's toy at them FRENCH ducks out of the way and the toy hits BILLY in the cheek. FRENCH draws his pistol and approaches the table. BRIAN rises and starts to flee. Cut off, he retreats the other way.
No, please...
Brian, stop it, I ain't gonna hurt you.
He fires, using a soda bottle as a silencer. BRIAN drops the floor. FRENCH approaches him assessing his victim. He turns to leave, passing BILLY.     He give him a slap.
Wake the fuck up.
They leave.

head_text.subj: EXT. A BEACH NEAR A POWERPLANT. DAY

text: BILLY leans against the wall of a concession stand. His knuckles are cut. A cut over his eye. He is agitated. Smoking. A car pulls up and Queenan and Dignam get out of In appearance, if anybody's watching, they're bracing Bil
Hey.   Let's go through the routine.
You think you can pop someone. There's no special card to play. The guy whose jaw you broke was Boston Police Department.
I'm going fuckin' nuts. I can't be someone else every day.
Most of the people in the world do it every day. What's the big deal?
Dignam is drinking coffee.
I'm not them.
You're nobody. You signed the paper. We're the only people in the world who know that you're a cop. Maybe we'll just erase your file.
This is Billy's deepest fear.
And zip, you're a soldier for Costello, open to arrest for how many felonies? Maybe we'll do that.
Maybe I'll fucking kill you.
He gets free of DIGNAM and punches him.
Easy now.    That was a joke, Billy.
Just because you play a fucking tough guy doesn't mean you are one, you lace curtain fucking pussy.
The fight. QUEENAN grabs Billy and holds him against the wall.
(gently, like a man calming a wild animal) Be smart. If someone was watching how are we supposed to not arrest you?
BILLY looks desperately inland. REVERE BEACH condominium buildings. A thousand empty terraces, five thousand empty windows. BILLY is desperate
Get in the car.
They do.
Keep your act together. It's just a little while longer.
BILLY nods, out of it. DIGNAM is looking at blood on his hands in disbelief.
When are you going to take Costello? What's wrong with taking 'em on any one of the million felonies you've seen him do. Get him for pissing in the street.
What, are you waiting for him to chop me up and feed me to the poor?
Well. That would stick...
You shut up. We're building a case. It takes time. You know that.
There's something wrong.
Maybe. Maybe.
Keep your ears opened.   No bullshit.
I want you to listen for any chatter about a spy in the Special Investigation Unit. (BILLY looks at him) You hear anything like that?
BILLY shakes his head.
Are you serious?
I'm afraid so.
Jesus H. Christ.
Hang tight for me. Just a little longer. We're this close.
BILLY nods reluctantly.
Okay.
Thank you, Billy
COLIN walks into the office. BROWN and other team members watching a closed-circuit monitor. The MONITOR shows FITZ sitting in an interrogation room. COLIN is spooked.
(to Brown) What have you got?
Uniform clipped him on the Pike for a suspended licence. However, as he's the subject of an open investigation----
At least one. He's one of Costello's crew.
----we're entitled to get a warrant. We can't get an address off him. He paged his lawyer but the lawyer hasn't called back yet.
Who's the lawyer?
He didn't know the name. He just had the number on a card. Beeper number.
Did he beep him?
Twice.
All right.
COLIN glances around and sees: a briefcase lying on a des He picks it up. He takes off his ID badge and tosses it o desk.
Give me your phone. (to Barrigan) Turn the camera off. Turn it off.
He takes Brown's cellphone out of Brown's pocket goes int the interrogation room.
What?
Give my your phone and turn the fucking camera off. Who's is this? I'm gonna take this.
He picks up a BRIEFCASE. BARRIGAN touches two buttons and switches off the sound recorder and video feed. COLIN goe into the interrogation room.
He can't do that, can he?
He just did.
FITZY looks up at COLIN hopefully. COLIN says nothing. He sits down, opens his case, takes out a yellow pad.
Mr. Fitzgibbon, afternoon.
You my attorney?
What do you think? Did you make any statements or phone calls I need to be aware of?
I beeped you. The card they gave me...that's it.
That's it? Don't you have to call your mother and tell her you're not gonna be home for supper?
ON FITZY. He looks up at the CCTV camera.
The cameras are off. (gently puts phone on the table) Call your mother.
Fitzy hesitates.
Lookit. They're in there suiting up for a raid. I don't know where they are going, but they do. And so do you. Call your mum.
COLIN puts a cellphone on the table. FITZY takes up the p and punches in a number. It is answered.
Mum, I'm not gonna make it for supper. I got held up. Yeah, talk to you later.

location: A HOUSE WHERE DRUGS ARE BEING HANDLED. CONTINUOUS

text: Everybody out. Move.

The DRUGS are swept up instantly, in sheets laid over the tables. MISTER FRENCH lights a cigarette with his ZIPPO, then reaches out and lights the curtains on fire as BILLY watches. INT. INTERROGATION ROOM. CONTINUOUS. COLIN takes the cellphone and puts it in his pocket.
Who are you? When do I get out of here?
I think you need another attorney, after all, Mr. Fitzgibbon. Have a nice day.
COLIN comes out and hands BROWN the CELLPHONE.
Run the last number called. That'll be his house. Whatever the location is I'll swear I surveilled him at it. Abracafuckindabra.
Why'd you use my phone?
Because you didn't go in there.
COLIN, hung-over, sits at the breakfast table.     Madoly at him.
The light's nice here in the morning.
COLIN doesn't respond.
It's all right. Guys tend to make a big deal out of it. It's actually quite common.
I gotta go to work.
COLIN simply gets up and walks away.
A clock ticking. Madolyn is looking across at ...Billy. Madolyn is very much a guarded shrink. But no one's more guarded than Billy.
It's like confession. Isn't it. This sort of thing.
A beat.
People make things up in confession. You know that?
I know they do.
People are liars. They want to be stars of their little films.
That's an interesting observation.
Do you lie?
Why do you?
I'm asking if you lie.
Honesty isn't synonymous with truth.
You lie. So, is it to do some good, to get somewhere personally, or just for the fuck of it?
I expect sometimes...people...do it to keep things...on an even keel.
So, you had a parent who was a drunk?
MADOLYN looks up at him, transpierced. Tables turned on t psychiatrist. BILLY smiles at her.
(flustered) Did you?
(simply) No.
Let's keep this with you.
(abruptly) There was a cop leaving when I came in.
How do you know he was a cop?
Bad haircut, no dress sense and a slight air of scumbag entitlement. You see cops?
That's part of what I do. Although, I don't normally see cadets who were kicked out of the Academy.
You should get a better job...
Do they all come in and cry...your cops?
Sometimes they cry if they had trouble at home or if they've had to...use their weapons.

Let me tell you something. They signed up to use their fuckin' weapons. Most of them. But they watch enough TV so they know they have to "weep" after they use their weapons. No one's more full of shit than a cop. Except a cop on TV.
I looked through your file and I see you have a record of assault. What was it like for you in jail?
You want to hear about the showers?
Did something happen to you?
No. (a beat) You sit there with a mass murderer, your heart-rate jacked, your hand...steady. That's one thing I found out about myself in prison. My hand doesn't shake, ever.
What do you expect from coming here?
I have to come here.
I know it's not elective...on your part...but, now that you're here, what do you want?
You want the truth? (a beat) Valium.
If you lied, you'd have an easier time getting what you wanted.
What's that say about what you do for a living?
Madolyn is taken aback. She closes her file.
Look, I think we better have a few more meetings before we can even talk about prescriptions.
She closes his file and puts it in the rack behind her.
I'm having panic attacks. You didn't even ask about that. Last night I thought I was having a fucking heart attack. I puked in a trash barrel on the way in here, I haven't slept for weeks.
Is this true?
Yes. I said something true. I want some fucking pills and you close my file? I thought I was supposed to tell the truth here.
Yes, you are.
If only fuckin' here.
She retrieves his folder.

(giving into stress) Guy comes in in pain, against every instinct of ...privacy, of, of, self reliance... that he has, and you don't help him? You send him off to score smack on the fucking street?! (Is that what you do, Mrs. Fuckin' Doctor?)
MADOLYN stares at him, then lowers her eyes, takes out a small packet of two pills. She hands it over to him. BILL looks at it.
Two pills.
She nods. BILLY reaches out and deliberately places the p on the desk.
Why don't you just give me a bottle of scotch and a handgun to blow my fucking head off. Are we done here with this psychiatry bullshit?
MADOLYN is taken aback, guilty, astonished.
You can leave!
What if that was a legitimate threat? (Hot shot).
BILLY leaves. MADOLYN stares after him.
Fuck...

text: Very windy. Papers blowing. Billy is walking. Madolyn cat up to him.
Why is the hardest patient of the day always the last one?
Because you're bored and tired and don't give a shit. It's not supernatural.

Madolyn holds out a paper and a business card.
What's this?
My card. And a prescription for twenty Lorazepam.
BILLY stands holding the prescription.
Is it enough to kill myself?

(she fixes him with a stare) Maybe it is. All right? Have I done my job up to your goddamned standards? Because by my standards you fit the model of drug-seeking behavior, and fuck you if you don't like my initial clinical reaction.
(re: prescription) Thank you.
I'm transferring you to another counselor.
She starts to go back inside.
You wanna get a cup of coffee?

It's an otherwise disused floor of a new luxury office building. Cables and monitors and computers everywhere. I crawling with State Cops as well as FBI (LAZIO is present very nattily dressed). COLIN comes in with BROWN and BARRIGAN. This operation is all new to Colin.

All right, let's bring it in, please. Come in please. (addressing room) Our target is a major transaction of microprocessors. Yes, those. I don't know what they are. You don't know what they are. Who gives a fuck? Cash will be handed over in a building which we have under AV surveillance. Staff Sergeant Sullivan's team... (he nods at COLIN) Will ID the bad guys and listen in on the phones.
(to his guys) Did you guys know anything about this?
No.
(to LAZIO) How long have we been tapped on this building?
Our unit will not take action until a man Captain Queenan has inside the operation has verified the transaction. Questions? Anyone? This is who we're after. (taps picture of Costello)
We've been after this cocksucker for a long time, and tonight we're gonna get him. Get to work.
ON COLIN as he reflexively touches his cell phone and thi about the best way out of this.
We've been after this son of a bitch for a long time, and we're getting him tonight. Get to work.
(to team) Go find out what we're doing and get on it.
COLIN wanders off in the mill of officers. He is taking o his cell phone when ELLERBY comes up to him.
Sorry to get you at the last minute. But things leak. This lead came from Queenan's undercover guy.
ELLERBY walks on to a COFFEE STATION, a yard away.
(into cell) Dad?
(on phone) Yes?
COLIN is completely normal on the phone.
I'm not going to make dinner. Something big has come up.
COSTELLO is on the phone.
Too bad. Your mother worked all goddamned day. We'll just have to sit down without you and your friends.
COLIN turns away from the activity.
Oh, my friends are still coming.
COLIN sees QUEENAN staring at him.
We'll just say lunch tomorrow.   All right, bye.
COLIN ends the call. QUEENAN is there.
The readiness is all. You know the players, call the game.
Thank you, Captain.
He gives him the clipboard, Colin goes to the work area.

COLIN joins his team (BROWN AND BARRIGAN), who are seated a U shaped work-area. COLIN, still stunned by the fact of this operations center, swallows as he notices on video t angles of a building he seems to know very well. He sits and puts a headset on. A GEEK COP leans over and shakes h hand.
Piece of cake. I'll operate the cameras. You ID the guys and log them.
COLIN nods. QUEENAN comes up.
All cellphone signals are under surveillance through the courtesy of our Federal friends over there...
COLIN looks: sees LAZIO and two others.
(as if on coke and he probably is) Patriot Act. Love it. Love it.

COLIN, using his left hand, not looking, opens his cellph autodials, and then taps an instant message into it, push "Send." DETAIL OF IM: "No Phones" ONSCREEN, CARS PULL UP IN FRONT OF THE TARGET BUILDING.
All right. That's Costello right there. Costello, Mister French, Fitzy, Delahunt, Billy Costigan the new guy...Time is 10.46.
Who are they meeting?
(leaning over screens) I don't know. Some Chinamen from points unknown. They're already inside.
DETAIL OF COLIN'S PHONE. COLIN hits "send", sending the message "No phones". THE SCREEN then reads "Erasing Sent Message".
COSTELLO and the boys go into the building, moving past T IDLING CARS. We see Costello look casually at his phone.
Watching images. COSTELLO'S GUYS move through pillars and disappear.
We have a blind spot.
Why do you have a blind spot?
We had two hour's notice. Two hours. What the fuck you think this is, NASA?
It never crossed my mind. You get a camera in the back?
What back?
Ellerby blows his nose. He is on coke. COLIN sends anothe TEXT MESSAGE: "Blind spot inside door."
COSTELLO looks at his IM screen and turns to his guys.
Turn off your cell phones.
FITZY and some others mutter.
Check your weapons...Fitzy has the chicken...

Everyone turns off their phones, including BILLY (but we Billy has TWO phones). BILLY looks around at the pillared distances. He sees: A GROUP OF THREE MEN waiting and FIVE OTHER MEN spreading through the pillars. Armed.
(to no one, and maybe OS) Maybe if we had some Homeland security money like some other fucking douchebags I could mention...
Both Brown and Colin have their headsets on.
Any calls?
They turned off their phones.
COLIN looks utterly innocent.
Search randomly for calls made from the area.
Eight hundred seven phones are live in this area.
Narrow the area.
What you see for coverage is what you get.
(like Queenan, an observer of Ellerby's operation) Why the fuck did they turn off their phones?
Wait, there's still one phone up.
Where?
A single light on the screen. QUEENAN looks at an IM (fro Billy) on his phone. DETAIL: "buyers here". ("$")
The buyers are there.
COLIN wonders how Queenan knew this. The single light win out on the screen. ELLERBY looks at Queenan, impressed.
You know, direct access to your fucking guys would have certain fuckin' advantages.
(mildly) Not to my guy.
ELLERBY stares at him.
This is unbelievable. (looking at screens) Fuck it, who put the cameras in the fucking place?
Who the fuck are you.
I'm the guy who does his job. You must be the other guy.
Hey, hey, hey...

text: COSTELLO'S BOYS spread out. Across the open, lumber-strew area, CHINESE GANG MEMBERS are waiting. (in Cantonese, not subtitled) Waiting, waiting. We almost departed! This man is from the Embassy. He will have to blow his brains out if he is captured. His entire family will be killed.
He's a little upset.
Tell him light on the starch.
BILLY is watching carefully. [As (INSERT) ONSCREEN in the OPERATIONS ROOM the last lights wink off...] He removes h hand from his pocket, having just switched off his phone.
(roughly translating) He's fronting the Chinese government and he's just scared shitless.
Government man. (loudly, to Chinese) I'm concerned about Chinamen who think it's wise to bring automatic weapons to a business transaction.
The CHINESE GANGSTER interjects --
Ngup, Ngup, Ngup. Ngaw um ming. Kay ngup mutt. [Yap, yap, yap. I don't understand. What is he saying?]
The CHINESE TRANSLATOR translates Costello's statement ab "concern." SEVERAL OF THE TRIAD, hearing a "automatic weapon," stupi raise their MACHINE GUNS. They don't aim them.
For his own good, tell Bruce Lee and the Karate Kids none of us are carrying automatic weapons because here, in this country, it don't add inches to your dick. You get a life sentence for it.

If these chinks want to nuke Taiwan any time in this century, you tell them they better shape up fast and show me one million dollars.

What we generally do in this country is one guy shows up with the items, and the other guy pays him. No tickee...no laundry.

Nay tiey ching chaw yut bok mon. [Make sure it's real. It's a million dollars.]. ALTERNATE/ALSO (insult): Ne dei yeeche ling ngnaw dong maw gok nay chun. [Next time you make me wait, I'm going to cut your dick off.
In English, thank you, also.
Du ne. [Fuck you.]
The deal is done.
The expedition continues this way.
To Billy's surprise both Costello's men and the Chinese h out through the back industrial windows onto a canal-side pier.
The CARS of the CHINESE GUYS are driven away, passing a v full of... Startled TACTICAL COPS. TWO TACTICAL UNITS are hidden outside.

Don't tell me those cars were empty. Please don't tell me those Chinamen's cars were empty. (to Camera Tech Cop) Do you have a camera in the back.
An IMAGE comes up. Nothing.
Can I talk to you a minute?
